A Paladin's Steam Review: The Novelist. Story Cliches and Unlikable Characters Abound.Genre: 1st Person Exploration Narrative Game.
Developed & Published by: Orthogonal Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Preamble
While this particular title dodged my radar last year, I gave it a try this year after seeing a review of it and being intrigued by it. Controlling a ghost following around a family and giving them directions on their life seemed like a pretty good idea for a videogame to explore. But was the execution solid? Read on.

Overall Gameplay
Each day is repetitive stream of the same tasks with slightly different flavor text. (Gather clues about what’s bothering each family member, see their memories then choose which solution you think is best all while avoiding being detected). The stealth is basic and is more a chore than fun as you just jump from light fixture to other light fixture, getting out of them only briefly to read some more text. The game even lets you turn the need for stealth off which I would recommend doing, if the story itself was more interesting.

My main problem with the story is that it uses way too many cliches with too many forced emotional scenes. To the point of finding myself detesting the game the longer I played it. There are choices that get way too unrealistic. There’s one part where a grandmother dies and the Novelist has to make the choice to either go to a book signing or go to the funeral to support his wife. The company he works for claims they can’t reschedule the book signing and that it would be very bad for him to miss it. I...I have a really hard time believing that they couldn't reschedule it due to a family member’s death. Even if I could buy that being a real situation, there’s another example that I found downright silly. It boils down to: Wife wants to camp far away and Son wants to camp close by. And if you don’t choose correctly, someone’s unhappy. What?! That’s like whining about getting two chocolate cookies instead of three. It feels like it was put in just to get an emotional reaction where all I could think is: “these are some real narcissistic people”.

Character flaws
Which is then followed by the worst problem this game has: we don’t have well fleshed out characters here. They are nothing but cliches. Despite spending quite a few intimate hours with them, I didn’t get any real connection with them.  There’s a writer who’s suffering from writer’s block. There’s a mother who wants to be an artist again. There’s a son being a generic kid. That’s all I remember about them. I will admit, that having cliche characters for us to project ourselves onto them may have been intentional game design. But I find it to be the experience to be less for it.

PC Settings
Most of the PC settings are there. You’ve got resolution, AA, V-Sync, subtitles, difficulty and voiceover reading if wanted. Graphically, the game isn’t all that impressive. It’s a weird pseudo CGI/Realistic style that is somehow lacking in detail. If it’s intentional, I’m not a fan of it. The soundtrack is a “depressing” solo piano that tries to bring emotional oomph to the game. However, it falls into the cliche area of soundtrack design and comes off as extremely flat when I played it. The game’s coding is solid, there weren’t any bugs, errors or crashes during my playthrough.

Final Thoughts
I have a hard time recommending this game. I’ve already hammered on the story quite a bit but I didn’t dig the cliche story, the cliche characters and I definitely hated the forced emotional moments caused by no-win choices by overly narcissistic characters. If you’re in a similar situation to the Novelist (struggling artist with a family), the game might speak to you and you might get something out of it. Otherwise, I’d look elsewhere.

Seemingly regular story about balancing a busy life and family.
You choose which activities the people do, benefitting some, disappointing others.

It's a decent idea and implmented well, but after every choice you see the impact it has on the others and it is too emotionally hard for me at this point in my life. I don't want to dissapoint that fictional wife, child or husband.
I can't play any more.

I recommend it, but it's not for me.

Not quite sure if I recommend this game or not. I guess it depends what kind of games you like.
Generally I like games that are fun rather than games that are a narrative experience.

I would categorize this as one of those experience type games. It did have some fun moments and the overall idea is pretty cool (but a bit creepy/strange).

Overall, if you like narrative focused games then you will like this, if you don't then just pass on this game. Personally I would rather just watch a movie or something instead of playing this game.
It's a short but sweet game that really hits home on its themes of family and what a legacy is
At it's best The Novelist is interesting - particularly when looking at how difficult being true to both yourself and the others you love.

I normally like exploration games because they're forced to tell a good story and the main mechanic is empathy. The Novelist, though, managed to annoy and make me wish for at least one of the characters to slip into a coma so they'd stop complaining so much. It's basically a story about three selfish people who live together and refuse to comunicate their needs or desires to each other so they just go around being passive agressive. You come in as Casper the friendly ghost who solves all their problems and yet they still act like spoilt brats and pout all day. In the end there's no real sense of completion since you know they'll just basically go back home and make each other miserable again.\nIf playing God is what you're into, go get yourself a copy of the Sims. At least it'll let you remove the pool ladder once in a while.

A man takes his wife & young son to a secluded vacation home so that he can focus on writing his next great novel; little do they know that the house is also home to an unknown supernatural force that can worm its way into the father's mind. No, it's not The Shining, it's The Novelist. In it you play a spirit (or something?? it's not actually specified) haunting a house on a cliff. Your goal is to influence the choices of the father/husband character, Dan, by learning as much as you can about him & his family through written & drawn clues scattered around the house as well as by entering each character's memories. Each chapter presents a situation to which there are three solutions: one that most benefits the dad, one the mom, & one the kid. You can also make a secondary compromise" choice that will at least partially satisfy one of the other characters if not totally please them.\n\nIf "Stealth" mode is enabled you have the potential of being spotted by the family while you gather clues during the day
date: which causes you to lose certain opportunities. You can become invisible & move from one place to the next without being seen by possessing the home's light fixtures
recommended: but you can't gather clues when you're in a lamp
hoursPlayed: so you also have the ability to make a light flicker to distract the family away from where you want to go. There is an alternate "Story" mode where you are invisible no matter where you are. In both modes there are some situations where characters will close doors on you (usually if they're mad about being neglected); you can't open or pass through the doors but the family usually opens them again soon enough. There's a subplot that involves gathering clues about the house's past
voteText: but that is not mutable based on the player's choices so it feels more like filler material.\n\nThe gameplay is fairly straightforward

& none too exciting (certainly nothing close to The Shining in that respect!).

Overall though this was a nice game to spend a bit of time on; it's pretty relaxing & there's definitely not anything high stress about it. I enjoyed playing through making choices "organically" the first time & then running through it quicker in subsequent replays to get different outcomes. I would definitely recommend doing "Stealth" mode for your first playthrough to get the most out of the experience; enable "Story" for replays so you can move from choice to choice & clue to clue much quicker & don't have to deal with spending time on repeated material. It goes quickly enough when you do that.

reviewText:
[ Fun: 7 | Plot: 8 | CTRL: 8 | GFX: 7 | SFX: 7 | Stable: Y | Replay: 6 ]
A haunting 7/10

+ Great plot with lots of feedback and additional info
+ Superb voice acting of which there could have been more
+ Possession and movement mechanics are really fun
+ Interesting and rewarding choice making system

~ Oddly several rooms are never or hardly used at all
~ Repetitive goals (3 memories, 3 primary choices, 3 secondary)
~ Environment is charming but barely changes with your choices

- Echoy audio in possessions rendered incomprehensible
- No secondary choice in the finale

The good

Getting into the character's minds and trying to balance the needs and desires of all three - not an easy task. Their personal stories were engaging too, and keep you interested

The bad

The three Kaplans do a lot of hand-wringing and worry worting. Some of their wants are ridiculous and unrealistic

I just completed this game after a short 95 minute run. I would only buy this game if you want to play over and over for a different outcome. It was a waste of money if you play this only once. I went in thinking it would be just another choice after choice and nothing happens, but this game will send chills down your spine with the soundtrack and the facts. It may seem like a fictional ghost story but this game is more than real. 7/10. Doing another run for sure.

Have been using this game to break up exam prep today - perfect decision.

Very sweet little game.

Most enjoyable.

A Paladin's Steam Review: The Novelist. Story Cliches and Unlikable Characters Abound.Genre: 1st Person Exploration Narrative Game.
Developed & Published by: Orthogonal Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Preamble
While this particular title dodged my radar last year, I gave it a try this year after seeing a review of it and being intrigued by it. Controlling a ghost following around a family and giving them directions on their life seemed like a pretty good idea for a videogame to explore. But was the execution solid? Read on.

Overall Gameplay
Each day is repetitive stream of the same tasks with slightly different flavor text. (Gather clues about what’s bothering each family member, see their memories then choose which solution you think is best all while avoiding being detected). The stealth is basic and is more a chore than fun as you just jump from light fixture to other light fixture, getting out of them only briefly to read some more text. The game even lets you turn the need for stealth off which I would recommend doing, if the story itself was more interesting.

My main problem with the story is that it uses way too many cliches with too many forced emotional scenes. To the point of finding myself detesting the game the longer I played it. There are choices that get way too unrealistic. There’s one part where a grandmother dies and the Novelist has to make the choice to either go to a book signing or go to the funeral to support his wife. The company he works for claims they can’t reschedule the book signing and that it would be very bad for him to miss it. I...I have a really hard time believing that they couldn't reschedule it due to a family member’s death. Even if I could buy that being a real situation, there’s another example that I found downright silly. It boils down to: Wife wants to camp far away and Son wants to camp close by. And if you don’t choose correctly, someone’s unhappy. What?! That’s like whining about getting two chocolate cookies instead of three. It feels like it was put in just to get an emotional reaction where all I could think is: “these are some real narcissistic people”.

Character flaws
Which is then followed by the worst problem this game has: we don’t have well fleshed out characters here. They are nothing but cliches. Despite spending quite a few intimate hours with them, I didn’t get any real connection with them.  There’s a writer who’s suffering from writer’s block. There’s a mother who wants to be an artist again. There’s a son being a generic kid. That’s all I remember about them. I will admit, that having cliche characters for us to project ourselves onto them may have been intentional game design. But I find it to be the experience to be less for it.

PC Settings
Most of the PC settings are there. You’ve got resolution, AA, V-Sync, subtitles, difficulty and voiceover reading if wanted. Graphically, the game isn’t all that impressive. It’s a weird pseudo CGI/Realistic style that is somehow lacking in detail. If it’s intentional, I’m not a fan of it. The soundtrack is a “depressing” solo piano that tries to bring emotional oomph to the game. However, it falls into the cliche area of soundtrack design and comes off as extremely flat when I played it. The game’s coding is solid, there weren’t any bugs, errors or crashes during my playthrough.

Final Thoughts
I have a hard time recommending this game. I’ve already hammered on the story quite a bit but I didn’t dig the cliche story, the cliche characters and I definitely hated the forced emotional moments caused by no-win choices by overly narcissistic characters. If you’re in a similar situation to the Novelist (struggling artist with a family), the game might speak to you and you might get something out of it. Otherwise, I’d look elsewhere.

Very fun and relaxing game, hoping to see another game like this.
It was a lot easier than expected to get a decent ending. I was expecting tears at the ending, but I was just glad it was over and I could move on.

I really loved this game. Played through with story mode just to get an idea of what I'd be getting myself into and could definitely see myself playing this again with stealth mode to see the challenge. I found it to be quite sweet in the way the story(ies) was told depending on your choices and made you consider priorities (work, family, life) to get the right 'balance'.\n\nIt falls more into the category of artistic/storytelling games but the game mechanics were decent and allowed enough exploration and player interaction to feel like a 'game'. I have no idea how varied the outcomes were, but it is that question that makes you want to start over from the beginning (and get your money worth).

The Novelist intends to reflect on the difficulty of juggling different aspects of life, but the way the story unfolds feels like nothing more than a basic decision tree, with a predictable structure that ultimately fails to deliver its point.
While the game only offers a handful of hours of gameplay for your first ending, it is a joy to play.

I bought this game on Christmas break of my Sophomore year because I was bored and it was on sale. It was such a fantastic decision.\nI'm a senior now and Christmas break just started and I'm re-playing for about the fourth time. I still love the game. This game's beautiful story is dripping with subtext and has helped me through some rough patches.\nThank you to the devs and I would recommend this game even at a AAA $60 price tag.

A nice relatively quick game to past the time. As the game progresses towards the end it becomes tiring on a two pronged level. On the one hand, the gameplay becomes a bit repetitive as each level you essentially do the same thing. However, the story and choices become much more emotionally" difficult to make. Depending on what you value as a person within your own life
date: the decision in the last chapters become some of the hardest to make. Those with a strong literary ties will struggle making the final decision."

reviewText: A slow paced game with a nice story.\nMore than just a walking simulator.

A choice based game where you play as a ghost like being who floats around getting to know the family and their problems. You can investigate and find out what each character wants, then at the end of the day whisper into Dan’s ear, what he should do. Pretty straight forward but you decisions keep caring over as the characters keep thinking about what they did or did not get to do. Are you going to be a helpful ghost? Or try to pull the family apart? Help Dan decide… if he even decides at all, or is it just you putting ideas there?

A short, fast game but definitely worth a replay to see how things would turn out differently when you favour one character over another.

7/10

I wouldn’t say it’s worth $17 CAD but a good game to get on sale!

reviewText:
Hello,

I do recommend this game to people who like game where the story can be influenced by their actions.
The graphics are simple, the stealth part is minimal (and that is a compliment, I do like stealth game a lot but this is not splinter cell kinda of game), and you don't even have to stealth through the game which the story mode in the option in which you can't be seen by the family.

What is really good is the voice acting and the story, which unfold by your actions.
Actions that sometimes you regret, A few of them, when learning the consequences, didn't felt rights. But that's how life is, you make choices which leads to some place you don't know yet, sometimes it's better and sometimes it's worse.
Trying to balance things out.

I finished the story in around 3h. This game have difinitively some replay value, what happens when I root for the child, mother or father? What about the mix of them?
And compremising differents choices by adding a choive for the mother to the choice for the child.
This part is really good to try, sometimes the compremise is great in the consequences.

I have one con from playing, some light can't be possess in stealth mode, I suppose it's not a bug but it was made to have some difficulty. It was just more frustrating than anything else, because it didn't felt right to that (my opinion ^_^). The game don't need difficulty I think, it's about the story, not being spot is part of it  but that shouldn't be the main element even in stealth mode.

Thanks to the author of the game. I had a great time! I will be watching to see something new from you ;).

Cheers,
Luuna.

A Very Unique Game of Guided Storytelling

In The Novelist, you take on the role of a ghost living in a house when a new family moves in.  The family are good people, but they've got problems.  Your job is to try to figure out what's going on in their lives and subtly influence their story by whispering to Dan (the dad) in his sleep to influence his decisions.  Then you get to see what happens.  Will you be able to keep their troubled marriage from falling apart?  Will their son grow up to be happy and well-adjusted?  It's up to you.

The coolest thing about the decisions you make, is that they are seldom good" and "bad."  Like in life
date: you've got to set priorities.  What's more important: Dan's career or spending time with his son?  Letting Dan's wife pursue her passion or letting his son pursue his?  It's impossible to make everyone happy
recommended:
and you'll have to make decisions that make you a little sad.

Pros:
* Unique.  It's nice to play something different once in a while.
* Story-driven with lots of depth and realism
* Like watching a movie where you get to influence the character's actions
* There's a certain hard-to-describe beauty about the whole game and experience

Cons:
* Could be boring for more active gamers.  This is **not** an action-packed game.  It's about story.  This can partially be helped by playing on Stealth mode
hoursPlayed: which means you have to stay hidden so that the family doesn't know they have a ghost
voteText: but even so the game requires patience and thinking
helpfulPercent: not button mashing.\n* The mechanics do start to get repetitive
votesHelpful: as every chapter follows the same formula.\n* The game is quite short.  I'd love to see a more epic version with a story that branches and is more complex."

reviewText:
A game in which you explore and make decisions for a 3 person family.

The game itself follows a set of events that happen in somewhat random order. The endings are entirely dependant on who you choose to help most often, and not at all on the content of those choices. That bothered me a little, as it means an afternoon playing a board game with the kid has exactly as much weight toward his eventual future as a decision to take weekly art classes has on the mother, or the decision to exercise regularly has on the father.

It's good for one playthrough if you like story games. After that you probably have a good idea what happens to different people if you choose to change who you help, and I don't think it would be worth tediously replaying the game to look at the different outcomes. Not the strongest recommendation, but at the same time it's not a bad game for what it is.

Bit of a mixed review here because I would totally reccomend it when it's on sale (ie right now), but I'm not sure I'd get it at full price. I like this method of story telling, and it was nice to have an effect on the story itself. The character's concerns made sense, and I was particularly interested in the history of the ghost that you play as. That said, I'm not sure it did all that it could have with the concept. I didn't feel super connected to the characters as people, which made the whole puppetteer of their lives thing a little weird for me. Plus, as a person who's played Gone Home, I know that the digging through people's things method of storytelling can be done so much better than this. By the end, finding the clues became more annoying than exciting, and very rarely were they illuminating enough to feel worth it. There was at least one chapter where the inability to make everyone ok with the situation didn't make much sense to me. I got this from a Humble Bundle that I only spent a dollar on so in that sense I'm totally happy with it. It was nice to float around helping someone get their life together as a break from real life, but I cannot say I would spend more than a couple bucks on this. I did not play on stealth mode though so maybe it's a more interesting mechanic when you're trying to hide from the Kaplans.
One of the best games I've ever played.\nSuch hard decisions... Definitely made me cry.\n10/10

Kinda like Gone Home, for those that thought Gone Home was too well-designed and needed less interesting characters. There's a thread of truth to its story, but it would've worked better as a Twine text adventure, and that's a hell of a downside for any game to inherit

A playthrough of this indie pet project reminds us of the tried and true Parker/Stone adage: When you have plot outlines and you can put the words "and then" in between each one
date: you're f***ked".\n\nThe Novelist's plot barely qualifies it for a listing at The Daytime Emmy Awards. Typical Hallmark-esque tribulations of a fading marriage
hoursPlayed: and a writer-protagonist so stereotypical that leaves the player wondering how boring the actual writer of this narrative actually is files this sappy indie title under "do something else with your morning".\n\nWhat's more
voteText: The Novelist serves as an example of why game mechanics simply cannot be bolted onto a story and the final build be thus christened a Game. It's odd that the designer opted for a "spectral" approach to experiencing the narrative. In other words
helpfulPercent: why is the player banished to look on the game's character as a non-character herself? The shoddy "novel within a novel" justification for the third person gameplay decision at the game's conclusion is a poor one at best.\n\nI'll save you yelling the "so-♥♥♥♥ing what?!" question at your monitor and instead

The Novelist is a game that falls into that bucket of games that aren't exactly interactive experiences like Dear Esther, but still not nearly as involved gameplay wise as the majority of mainstream FPS games.  The title sees you patrolling the Summer home of a frustrated author and his single unit family as some sort of presence" or "ghost".  There are two distinct game "difficulties"

Rating: 4/10

A while back, I received this game among a bunch of others in a Humble Bundle. Since this isn't typically the genre of game that I play, I added it to my library and promptly forgot about it. Just a few days ago, upon noticing the game in my library, I installed it with the intent of farming some steam trading cards and deleting it afterwards.

Allow me to say that I am *SO* glad that curriosity got the better of me and I decided to give the game a try. In complete honesty, I can say that I don't think I've ever become so emotionally invested in a game's fictional family as I did with the Kaplans.

This being said, I would recommend that anyone playing this game should play it in Story mode as opposed to Stealth mode. The stealth mechanic can get a bit annoying and clunky, while also making the Kaplans' stories that much less immersive than you building/observing their lives free-rein. This puts a greatter emphasis on the game's Story-Rich" tag
recommended: which in turn--I believe--plays to its strengths."

reviewText: Gave up everything for my family.\n\n10/10 would be broke and unemployed again.

Firstly, this game has the best premise ever. In first-person, you play a meddling ghost who fixes" people's lives by telling them what to do. This is one of my favorite things to do in real life.\n\nThat aside
date: whether you'll like this game will be entirely dependent on whether you identify with the story or not. What some people here have called "mundane" and "boring
recommended: I would call realistic and relatable. The plot is about making various difficult and sometimes heartbreaking choices, and the sacrifices family members make for each other. Personally, I think it's very touching and well-written. I've never played another game quite like this.

reviewText: Good.

The Novelist is a nice, short game where you are playing as a ghost-like entity haunting family of three. You can influence the choices of the father of the family - prioritize between desires of himself, his wife, and his son. There's some replayability value, as different choices provide you with different game outcomes.
